1.brief: properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Ijob, the patriarch famous for his patience

2.brief: properly, to toss, i.e. grapple; mostly figuratively, to wrangle, i.e. hold a controversy; (by implication) to defend
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
to be right (i.e. correct); reciprocal, to argue; causatively, to decide, justify or convict
properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce

3.brief: properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
Ijob, the patriarch famous for his patience
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

4.brief: to be (causatively, make) light, literally (swift, small, sharp, etc.) or figuratively (easy, trifling, vile, etc.)

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to

5.brief: properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to add or augment (often adverbial, to continue to do a thing)

6.brief: properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Ijob, the patriarch famous for his patience
properly, a part of; hence (prepositionally), from or out of in many senses

7.brief: 'I pray', 'now', or 'then'; added mostly to verbs (in the Imperative or Future), or to interjections, occasionally to an adverb or conjunction
properly, a valiant man or warrior; generally, a person simply
the loins (as the seat of vigor)
to inquire; by implication, to request; by extension, to demand

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)

8.brief: meaning accession (used as an adverb or conjunction); also or yea; adversatively though
to break up (usually figuratively), i.e. to violate, frustrate

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
to be (causatively, do or declare) wrong; by implication, to disturb, violate
properly, heed, i.e. purpose; used only adverbially, on account of (as a motive or an aim), teleologically, in order that
to be (causatively, make) right (in a moral or forensic sense)

9.brief: used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
the arm (as stretched out), or (of animals) the foreleg; figuratively, force
strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
a form of the prefix 'k-', but used separately  as, thus, so
to tumble, i.e. be violently agitated; specifically, to crash (of thunder); figuratively, to irritate (with anger)

10.brief: to advance, i.e. pass on or continue; causatively, to remove; specifically, to bedeck (i.e. bring an ornament upon)
'I pray', 'now', or 'then'; added mostly to verbs (in the Imperative or Future), or to interjections, occasionally to an adverb or conjunction
grandeur (i.e. an imposing form and appearance)
properly, wrap around, i.e. (by implication) to put on agarment or clothe (oneself, or another), literally or figuratively

11.brief: to dash in pieces, literally or figuratively (especially to disperse)
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to depress or sink (expectation figuratively, to humiliate, intransitive or transitive)

12.brief: to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, to bend the knee; hence, to humiliate, vanquish
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.

13.brief: dust (as powdered or gray); hence, clay, earth, mud
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
to wrap firmly (especially a turban, compress, or saddle); figuratively, to stop, to rule

14.brief: properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and
physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, to be open, wide or free, i.e. (by implication) to be safe; causatively, to free or succor
the right hand or side (leg, eye) of a person or other object (as the stronger and more dexterous); locally, the south

15.brief: 'I pray', 'now', or 'then'; added mostly to verbs (in the Imperative or Future), or to interjections, occasionally to an adverb or conjunction
a water-ox, i.e. the hippopotamus or Nile-horse
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
beef cattle or an animal of the ox family of either gender (as used for plowing); collectively, a herd

16.brief: 'I pray', 'now', or 'then'; added mostly to verbs (in the Imperative or Future), or to interjections, occasionally to an adverb or conjunction
vigor, literally (force, in a good or a bad sense) or figuratively (capacity, means, produce); also (from its hardiness) a large lizard
properly, the waist or small of the back; only in plural the loins
the belly, especially the womb; also the bosom or body of anything

17.brief: properly, to incline to; by implication (literally but rarely) to bend; figuratively, to be pleased with, desire
a form of the prefix 'k-', but used separately  as, thus, so
a cedar tree (from the tenacity of its roots)
a thong (as compressing); by analogy, a tendon
a testicle (as a cause of shame akin to fear)

18.brief: a bone (as strong); by extension, the body; figuratively, the substance, i.e. (as pron.) selfsame
properly, containing, i.e. a tube; also a bed or valley of astream; also a strong thing or a hero
a bone (as the skeleton of the body); hence, self, i.e. (figuratively) very
iron (as cutting); by extension, an iron implement

19.brief: he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
the first, in place, time, order or rank (specifically, a firstfruit)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application

to be or come (causatively, bring) near (for any purpose); euphemistically, to lie with a woman; as an enemy, to attack; religious to worship; causatively, to present; figuratively, to adduce an argument; by reversal, to stand back
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement

20.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
to laugh (in pleasure or detraction); by implication, to play
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence

21.brief: the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
to lie down (for rest, sexual connection, decease or any other purpose)
a cover (in a good or a bad, a literal or a figurative sense)
a reed (as erect); by resemblance a rod (especially for measuring), shaft, tube, stem, the radius (of the arm), beam (of a steelyard)

22.brief: properly, to entwine as ascreen; by implication, to fence in, cover over, (figuratively) protect
to revolve, surround, or border; used in various applications, literally and figuratively
a willow (from the use of osiers as wattles)
a stream, especially a winter torrent; (by implication) a (narrow) valley (in which a brook runs); also a shaft (of a mine)

23.brief: to press upon, i.e. oppress, defraud, violate, overflow
a stream (including the sea; expectation the Nile, Euphrates, etc.); figuratively, prosperity
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to start up suddenly, i.e. (by implication) to hasten away, to fear
figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to gush forth (as water), generally to issue
Jarden, the principal river of Palestine
near, with or among; often in general, to
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to

24.brief: an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
a noose (for catching animals) (literally or figuratively); by implication, a hook (for the nose)
to puncture, literally (to perforate, with more or less violence) or figuratively (to specify, designate, libel)
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire
